citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The written program of veterinary care is missing and was unavailable for inspection by APHIS officials. Animal health
may be compromised without readily available veterinary guidance. Applicant shall employ an attending veterinarian
under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal
arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The male Australian Shepard, USDA tag #2 known as "Red", has several live ticks embedded in his skin. Three were
found and removed. One was fully engorged, despite him wearing a flea and tick collar. Ticks transmit various diseases
which can negatively impact animal health. Applicant shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and
treat diseases and injuries, including effective tick control.
This is a 1st re-license Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by September 13, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next re-license Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
Alexandra Calderon, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The written program of veterinary care is missing and was unavailable for inspection by APHIS officials. Animal health 
may be compromised without readily available veterinary guidance. Applicant shall employ an attending veterinarian 
under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal 
arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises. 
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The male Australian Shepard, USDA tag #2 known as "Red", has several live ticks embedded in his skin. Three were 
found and removed. One was fully engorged, despite him wearing a flea and tick collar. Ticks transmit various diseases 
which can negatively impact animal health. Applicant shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and 
treat diseases and injuries, including effective tick control. 
 
This is a 1st re-license Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by September 13, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next re-license Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Alexandra Calderon, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
